title: Salt of the Earth tells the story of photographer Sebastião Salgado
text:
View
comments
Brazilian photographer, Sebastião Salgado has travelled to over a hundred countries to capture the ever-changing face of nature and humanity.
The former economist, who started taking photos in his thirties, made it his life's mission to document some of the darkest elements of life: from poverty to the plight of refugees. He went on to become one of the greatest photographers of our time.
A new Oscar-nominated film, Salt of the Earth, tells his story, as seen through the eyes of his son Juliano, who went with him during his last travels, and by Wim Wenders, himself a photographer.
The land of extremes: A woman dressed in fur makes her way thought the snow in the Yamal peninsula, in Siberia, Russia
Salgado has travelled to some of the world's most remote locations visiting little-known tribes and war stricken communities in order to present the fragility of human nature.
He has long since captured conflicts and suffering and is now working on a project on the the discovery of pristine territories, of wild fauna and flora in a tribute to the planet's beauty.

It's an endless story, a tale of madness.'
Portrait of a blind Tuareg woman. The photographer has captured conflicts and suffering during his prolific 40 year career
He is passionate about wildlife and worked on the restoration of part of the Atlantic Forest in Brazil, succeeding in helping to turn the area into a nature reserve in 1998, as well as creating the Instituto Terra, an environmental NGO dedicated to a mission of reforestation, conservation, and education.
Born in 1944, in Minas Gerais, Salgado now lives in France. He was won a string of major photographic awards, and is a UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador, and an honorary member of the Academy of Arts and Sciences in the United States.
The film showcases some of his most astonishing work, with a commentary narrating some of the highlights from the his four decade career. In it, Salgado explains how he took some of his best-known images.
Its director, photographer Wim Wenders worked closely with Salado junior to bring audiences the story of this phenomenal man.
